explicatoryContent.conceptExplanation:
Every living thing is made of tiny building blocks called cells. Inside most cells, there is a special part called the nucleus. The nucleus contains DNA, which looks like a twisted ladder. This shape is called a double helix.

DNA carries information in a code. Different parts of the DNA code for different things. These sections are called genes. You have genes for eye colour, hair colour, how tall you might grow, and thousands of other features.

When parents have children, they pass on their DNA. You got half your DNA from your biological mother and half from your biological father. This is why you might look a bit like both of them, but not exactly like either one.

Some traits are dominant, which means they show up more easily. Other traits are recessive, which means they are hidden unless you get them from both parents. For example, brown eyes are often dominant over blue eyes.

First Nations Australians have understood for thousands of years that features are passed from parents to children. They used this knowledge to breed plants and animals with useful traits. Today, scientists use genetics in medicine, farming, and many other areas.

caseStudy.title: The Curly Coat Mystery
caseStudy.scenario:
Mia's family has a dog named Buster who has straight fur. They decide to breed Buster with their neighbour's dog, Rosie, who also has straight fur. Surprisingly, one of the puppies, called Patches, has curly fur!

Mia is confused. 'How can Patches have curly fur when both parents have straight fur?' she asks her science teacher.

Her teacher explains that both Buster and Rosie must carry a hidden gene for curly fur. Even though the straight fur gene is dominant (it shows), they each have one recessive curly fur gene that they don't show. When Patches inherited the curly gene from both parents, the curly trait appeared.

Mia's teacher draws a Punnett square to show how this works. Using S for straight (dominant) and s for curly (recessive), both parents are Ss. The Punnett square shows that one in four puppies could be ss (curly).

explicatoryContent.conceptExplanation:
DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid) is found in the nucleus of cells and carries all the genetic information needed to build and maintain an organism. The DNA molecule looks like a twisted ladder, called a double helix. The sides of the ladder are made of alternating sugar and phosphate molecules. The rungs are made of pairs of bases.

There are four bases in DNA: adenine (A), thymine (T), guanine (G), and cytosine (C). These bases always pair in a specific way: A pairs with T, and G pairs with C. This is called complementary base pairing.

Genes are sections of DNA that contain instructions for making proteins. Proteins carry out most of the work in cells and determine many of our traits. Different versions of the same gene are called alleles. For example, there might be an allele for brown eyes and an allele for blue eyes.

When organisms reproduce, they pass on their alleles to their offspring. Each parent contributes one allele for each gene. The combination of alleles is called the genotype. The physical characteristic that results is called the phenotype. Some alleles are dominant, meaning they show their effect even when paired with a different allele. Recessive alleles only show their effect when two copies are present.

Punnett squares are tools that help predict the possible combinations of alleles in offspring. By understanding these patterns, scientists can predict the likelihood of certain traits appearing in the next generation.

caseStudy.title: Selective Breeding in Wollemi Pines
caseStudy.scenario:
The Wollemi Pine was discovered in 1994 in a remote canyon in New South Wales. With fewer than 100 trees remaining in the wild, scientists needed to increase the population without losing genetic diversity.

Dr. Cathy Offord from the Australian Botanic Garden led conservation efforts. The team collected seeds and took cuttings from different trees to grow new plants. They carefully tracked which plants came from which parent trees to maintain genetic diversity.

However, they discovered a problem: all wild Wollemi Pines are genetically very similar, likely due to past population bottlenecks. This low genetic diversity means the species is vulnerable to diseases—if one tree is susceptible, they probably all are.

The team now works to protect the wild population from disease while growing diverse collections in botanical gardens around Australia.

explicatoryContent.conceptExplanation:
DNA is the molecule that carries genetic information in almost all living organisms. Its structure—the double helix—was first described in 1953, though Rosalind Franklin's X-ray crystallography work was crucial to this discovery. The DNA molecule consists of two strands wound around each other, connected by paired bases.

Each strand is made of nucleotides, which have three components: a deoxyribose sugar, a phosphate group, and one of four nitrogenous bases (adenine, thymine, guanine, or cytosine). The sugars and phosphates form the 'backbone' of the strand. The bases face inward and pair with bases on the opposite strand: adenine always pairs with thymine (A-T), and guanine always pairs with cytosine (G-C). This complementary base pairing is crucial for DNA replication—when cells divide, each strand serves as a template for building a new complementary strand.

Genes are specific sequences of DNA bases that contain instructions for making proteins. The sequence of bases (the genetic code) determines which amino acids are joined together to form a protein. Proteins carry out most of the work in cells and are responsible for many traits. For example, proteins determine eye colour, blood type, and enzyme function.

Organisms inherit alleles (versions of genes) from their parents. Each parent contributes one allele for each gene. The combination of alleles (genotype) determines the trait that is expressed (phenotype). Punnett squares help predict the probability of different genotypes and phenotypes in offspring.

Genetic variation—differences in DNA between individuals—arises through several mechanisms. Mutations are random changes to DNA sequences. Sexual reproduction combines alleles from two parents in new combinations. Independent assortment during meiosis creates further variation. This genetic variation is the raw material for natural selection and evolution.

caseStudy.title: CRISPR and the Genetic Revolution
caseStudy.scenario:
In 2018, scientist He Jiankui announced he had used CRISPR gene-editing technology to modify the DNA of twin girls, attempting to make them resistant to HIV. The announcement created international controversy and He was later imprisoned.

CRISPR (Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats) is a powerful genetic tool that allows scientists to precisely edit DNA sequences. It was developed from a natural system bacteria use to defend against viruses. Scientists Jennifer Doudna and Emmanuelle Charpentier received the 2020 Nobel Prize for developing CRISPR as a gene-editing tool.

In Australia, CSIRO scientists are using CRISPR to develop disease-resistant crops and control invasive species. However, editing human embryos (like He's experiment) is banned in most countries because the changes would be passed to future generations, raising profound ethical concerns.

The scientific community must now grapple with where to draw the line between beneficial applications (treating genetic diseases) and problematic ones (enhancing human traits or making heritable changes).

relational.stem: Explain HOW the structure of DNA enables it to be accurately replicated.
relational.modelResponse: DNA's structure enables accurate replication through complementary base pairing. The double helix unwinds and the two strands separate. Each strand then acts as a template for building a new complementary strand. Because A always pairs with T and G always pairs with C, enzymes can read the sequence on one strand and add the correct complementary bases to build a new strand. This results in two identical DNA molecules, each containing one original strand and one new strand. The hydrogen bonds between base pairs are weak enough to allow separation but provide the precise matching needed for accurate copying.
relational.rubric: Clearly explains the relationship between DNA structure and replication accuracy

extendedAbstract.stem: Evaluate how understanding of DNA and inheritance has changed scientific thinking about evolution, and predict how future genetic technologies might further influence evolutionary theory.
extendedAbstract.modelResponse: Understanding DNA transformed evolutionary theory by providing the molecular mechanism for inheritance that Darwin lacked. We now know that evolution occurs through changes in allele frequencies, driven by mutation, natural selection, and genetic drift. DNA analysis has revealed evolutionary relationships between species (phylogenetics) and shown that all life shares common ancestry. Looking forward, technologies like CRISPR could allow intentional direction of evolution through gene drives or genome editing. This raises the possibility of 'synthetic evolution' where humans deliberately alter species' genomes. Advanced sequencing might reveal new forms of inheritance (like epigenetics) that expand our understanding of evolution. However, these advances also raise ethical questions about humans directing evolution and potentially creating irreversible changes to ecosystems.
extendedAbstract.rubric: Demonstrates sophisticated understanding of the relationship between genetics and evolution

explicatoryContent.conceptExplanation:
The central dogma of molecular biology describes how genetic information is expressed. DNA stores genetic information in the sequence of bases along its strands. During transcription, one strand of DNA serves as a template for synthesising messenger RNA (mRNA). RNA polymerase reads the DNA and builds a complementary mRNA strand using RNA nucleotides (with uracil replacing thymine). The mRNA then moves to ribosomes, where translation occurs.

During translation, the mRNA sequence is read in groups of three bases called codons. Each codon specifies a particular amino acid (or a stop signal). Transfer RNA (tRNA) molecules bring the correct amino acids to the ribosome, where they are joined together to form a protein chain. The sequence of codons in mRNA determines the sequence of amino acids in the protein, which determines the protein's structure and function.

Mendel's laws describe inheritance patterns. The law of segregation states that organisms have two alleles for each gene, and these separate during gamete formation so each gamete receives one allele. The law of independent assortment states that genes for different traits segregate independently (when on different chromosomes).

However, not all inheritance follows simple Mendelian patterns. In incomplete dominance, heterozygotes show an intermediate phenotype (e.g., red × white = pink flowers). In codominance, both alleles are fully expressed (e.g., AB blood type). Sex-linked traits are carried on sex chromosomes and show different inheritance patterns in males and females.

Genetic technologies now allow us to read (sequencing), edit (CRISPR), and transfer (genetic engineering) genetic information. These technologies have applications in medicine (gene therapy, genetic testing), agriculture (GM crops), and conservation (genetic rescue of endangered species). Understanding the science behind these technologies is essential for evaluating their benefits and risks.

caseStudy.title: The Genetic Rescue of the Orange-bellied Parrot
caseStudy.scenario:
The orange-bellied parrot is one of Australia's most endangered birds, with fewer than 50 individuals remaining in the wild. The tiny population faces extinction partly due to genetic problems resulting from inbreeding.

Dr. Catherine Grueber from the University of Sydney leads genetic research to save the species. Her team uses DNA analysis to measure genetic diversity in the population and identify the most genetically valuable individuals for breeding programs. They found that the wild population has very low genetic diversity—many individuals are as related as siblings.

The team developed a 'genetic rescue' strategy. They identified captive birds with rare alleles (genetic variations) and prioritised these for release to the wild population. They also use genetic matching to pair breeding birds to minimise inbreeding and maintain what genetic diversity remains.

The work extends beyond genetics: understanding which genes affect survival helps identify habitat requirements and inform broader conservation strategies. First Nations communities, including the palawa people of Tasmania, are involved in conservation efforts, connecting scientific approaches with traditional ecological knowledge.

relational.stem: Explain HOW understanding Mendel's laws helps us predict inheritance patterns, and WHERE the molecular basis of these laws occurs in cells.
relational.modelResponse: Mendel's laws describe predictable patterns of inheritance. The law of segregation states that alleles separate during gamete formation—this occurs during meiosis when homologous chromosomes are pulled apart, so each gamete receives one allele per gene. The law of independent assortment states that genes for different traits segregate independently—this occurs because chromosomes align randomly at metaphase of meiosis I, so the alleles on different chromosomes are distributed independently into gametes. Understanding these laws at the molecular level allows us to use Punnett squares to predict offspring ratios, because the probabilities of inheriting each allele follow the random processes of meiosis.
relational.rubric: Connects Mendelian principles to cellular and molecular processes

extendedAbstract.stem: Synthesise your understanding of genetics to evaluate whether de-extinction—using genetic technology to bring back extinct species like the thylacine—is scientifically feasible and ethically justifiable.
extendedAbstract.modelResponse:
De-extinction raises profound scientific and ethical questions. Scientifically, technologies like CRISPR and cloning offer theoretical pathways: comparing DNA from preserved specimens with related living species could identify key genetic differences, and gene editing could modify a surrogate genome. However, significant challenges remain. Ancient DNA is often degraded and incomplete. Even with a complete genome, we would need to recreate the epigenetic programming, mitochondrial DNA, and developmental environment. The resulting organism would differ from the original species.

Ethically, arguments for de-extinction include restoring biodiversity, reversing human-caused extinctions, and ecological benefits. Arguments against include resource diversion from protecting endangered species, inability to restore original ecosystems, and animal welfare concerns for surrogate mothers and first-generation offspring. First Nations peoples may have cultural concerns about disturbing species with spiritual significance.

A nuanced position might support de-extinction research while prioritising protection of existing species, and requiring extensive consultation with Indigenous communities before any thylacine de-extinction attempt.

explicatoryContent.introduction: The elegance of DNA's structure belies the complexity of gene expression and inheritance. While the central dogma provides a framework, modern molecular biology reveals layers of regulation, from chromatin structure to epigenetics, that determine how genotype translates to phenotype. Understanding these mechanisms illuminates both the power and limitations of genetic technologies, and raises profound questions about human intervention in hereditary processes.
keyPoints: Gene expression is regulated at multiple levels: transcription, post-transcription, translation, and post-translation
Epigenetic modifications affect gene expression without changing DNA sequence
Complex traits result from interactions between multiple genes (polygenic) and gene-environment interactions
Epistasis occurs when genes at different loci interact to influence phenotype

explicatoryContent.conceptExplanation:
The relationship between genotype and phenotype is far more complex than simple Mendelian ratios suggest. Gene expression—the process by which genetic information produces functional products—is regulated at multiple levels, allowing the same genome to produce hundreds of different cell types in a single organism.

Transcriptional regulation determines whether and how much a gene is transcribed. Promoter regions and enhancers control RNA polymerase access to genes. Transcription factors bind to DNA and either activate or repress transcription. Epigenetic modifications, including DNA methylation and histone modification, affect chromatin structure and gene accessibility without changing the DNA sequence. Remarkably, some epigenetic modifications can be inherited across generations, challenging traditional views of inheritance.

Post-transcriptional regulation includes alternative splicing (producing different proteins from the same gene), mRNA stability, and microRNA-mediated regulation. Translational and post-translational regulation further modulate protein production and activity.

Complex traits like height, intelligence, and disease susceptibility involve polygenic inheritance—many genes each contributing small effects—combined with environmental influences. Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have identified genetic variants associated with complex traits, but typically each variant explains only a small fraction of trait variation.

Epistasis adds another layer of complexity: genes interact with each other, such that the effect of one gene depends on the genotype at another locus. For example, coat colour in Labrador dogs involves two genes: one for pigment production and one for pigment deposition. A dog homozygous for the 'no deposition' allele will be yellow regardless of its pigment genotype.

These insights have profound implications for genetic technologies. The complexity of gene regulation means that genetic modifications may have unexpected effects. Personalised medicine must account for individual genetic variation. Gene editing raises questions about consent, equity, and the boundaries of human intervention in natural processes.

caseStudy.title: The Epigenetics of Trauma: Transgenerational Inheritance
caseStudy.scenario:
Research on the descendants of Holocaust survivors has revealed surprising findings about epigenetic inheritance. Studies led by Dr. Rachel Yehuda at Mount Sinai Hospital found that children of Holocaust survivors had altered stress hormone profiles compared to control groups—despite never experiencing the trauma themselves.

The proposed mechanism is epigenetic: severe trauma in parents may cause epigenetic modifications (such as DNA methylation changes in stress-response genes) that are transmitted to offspring through gametes. Similar findings have emerged from studies of famine survivors, traumatic stress, and environmental exposures.

These findings raise profound questions. If experiences can modify our epigenome in heritable ways, then environmental effects can be 'remembered' across generations—a mechanism beyond traditional Mendelian inheritance. This has implications for understanding health disparities, including the effects of colonisation on Indigenous populations.

However, the field remains controversial. Critics note that many studies are small, findings are difficult to replicate, and distinguishing epigenetic effects from social/cultural transmission of trauma is methodologically challenging.

multistructural.stem: Describe FOUR levels at which gene expression can be regulated.
multistructural.modelResponse: 1) Chromatin remodelling/epigenetic regulation: DNA accessibility determined by methylation and histone modifications; 2) Transcriptional regulation: Transcription factors and regulatory sequences control whether genes are transcribed; 3) Post-transcriptional regulation: Alternative splicing, mRNA stability, and microRNAs affect which mRNAs produce protein; 4) Translational/post-translational regulation: Control of translation rate and protein modification/degradation.

relational.stem: Explain HOW epistasis demonstrates that genes do not act in isolation, using a specific example to illustrate your answer.
relational.modelResponse: Epistasis shows that genes do not act in isolation because the phenotypic effect of one gene depends on the genotype at another locus. In Labrador coat colour, gene E controls whether pigment is deposited in fur, while gene B controls whether that pigment is black or brown. A dog with genotype ee cannot deposit any pigment, so it will be yellow regardless of whether it has B or b alleles. The E gene is epistatic to the B gene—it masks or modifies B's effect. This demonstrates that genes interact in pathways: the protein product of one gene may be required for another gene's product to function. Understanding these interactions is essential because they mean phenotypic outcomes cannot be predicted from individual gene effects alone.
relational.rubric: Clearly explains epistasis concept with specific example showing gene interaction

extendedAbstract.stem: Critically analyse how emerging understanding of epigenetic inheritance challenges traditional concepts of nature versus nurture, and evaluate the implications for our understanding of heredity, evolution, and social policy.
extendedAbstract.modelResponse:
Epigenetic inheritance fundamentally challenges the nature-nurture dichotomy by revealing that environmental experiences can create heritable changes. Traditionally, 'nature' referred to genetic inheritance (DNA sequence) while 'nurture' referred to environmental effects that were not inherited. Epigenetics blurs this boundary: environmental factors (nutrition, stress, toxins) can modify gene expression through DNA methylation and histone modification, and some of these modifications can be transmitted to offspring.

For heredity, this means that inheritance encompasses more than DNA sequence. A parent's experiences may influence offspring phenotype through epigenetic marks transmitted via gametes. This has been demonstrated in animal studies and suggested in human studies of famine, trauma, and environmental exposures.

For evolution, epigenetic inheritance provides an additional mechanism for phenotypic change across generations. While natural selection acts primarily on genetic variation, epigenetic variation might allow faster adaptive responses to environmental change. Some argue this represents 'Lamarckian' inheritance of acquired characteristics, though the mechanisms differ from what Lamarck proposed.

For social policy, the implications are profound. If adversity (poverty, discrimination, trauma) can have transgenerational epigenetic effects, this provides biological support for addressing systemic inequalities. It may help explain health disparities in colonised Indigenous populations. However, there are risks: epigenetic determinism could be misused to blame victims or their ancestors, or to justify eugenic interventions. The science is still developing, and we must be cautious about policy applications before mechanisms are fully understood.
